div.p: The training was 12 weeks and basically you sort of touched the basics of every aspect of the job so down to breathing apparatus,
fighting fires, learning about fire behaviour, road traffic accidents, different cutting techniques, rescue techniques, yeah anything
to do with the job basically and it was just sort of repetition doing it over and over and over again so that by the time you do get
to a station you sort of had the basics to then learn more while you’re on the job. When I first went to training school, the first week
and they actually stood for parade and they stood for attention and all that and roll call numbers and it was like
“Squad attention... Numbers one to four...” and I was like “I ain’t in the Army I’m here for fire fighting” so I didn’t actually
so maybe that’s ignorance on my part but I didn’t realise that Fire Fighters sort of took that sort of Army sort of role as well
because I didn’t realise you had so much people from the Navy and the Forces go into the Fire Service, I thought it was...
the way it was advertised was like it was a community role and obviously you’re fighting fires and stuff like that but I didn’t realise
the structure, I didn’t realise about you know your Sub-Officer and your Watch Manager and your ranking, I didn’t realise
it was all that officer rank stuff...
